Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group 2025 The Author(s) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial License ( http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ Abstract Background Metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC) is a serious medical emergency that can complicate the course of various malignancies, including prostate, breast, and lung cancers. Appropriate evaluation and effective management of MSCC early in the emergency department are necessary to minimize neurologic deterioration and optimize the trajectory of patient recovery. Methods This literature review examines and summarizes current evidence surrounding the emergency department approach for timely recognition, initial evaluation, and management of MSCC. Results A comprehensive clinical history, nerve root or spinal cord clinical examination, and urgent imaging procedures are fundamental for early diagnosis and initial management. The urgency of intervention depends on the rate of onset of motor deficits, which can progress during work-up. Patients should be stratified into subgroups: those requiring immediate surgery, those who can be treated with radiotherapy, and those who may be discharged for outpatient care. Some patients can be observed for 24 h to adjust the medical and/or surgical treatment. In most cases, systemic steroid administration with dexamethasone should be started immediately upon diagnosis, followed by a tapering course of oral dexamethasone. Selected patients should undergo surgical decompression with or without stabilization. A multidisciplinary approach involving both spinal surgeons and radiation oncologists is essential for diagnosis and stratification. Conclusion For patients with MSCC, early and effective evaluation and intervention in the emergency department, through a coordinated multidisciplinary effort, are vital to optimizing patient outcomes. Background Metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC) is a serious condition that can complicate the course of various malignancies. While spinal cord compression lacks a standardized definition, MSCC usually presents with several neoplastic deposits in the vertebral column or the epidural space that cause pressure on the spinal cord. Prostate, breast, and pulmonary malignancies are well known for their predilection for spinal involvement and together constitute 45%-60% of MSCC instances [ 1 2 Given the complexity of MSCC management in the emergency room, the appropriate disposition of patients with MSCC is essential for timely and comprehensive care. The disposition depends on the severity of a patient’s clinical presentation. Stable patients with strong home support can opt for outpatient care with follow-up. Some may need up to 24 h of clinic observation. Severe cases require urgent inpatient admission and potential surgery. Consultative services from radiation oncology or neurosurgery may be appropriate to determine the best treatment pathway between radiotherapy, surgical de-compression, or a combined treatment approach. Dexamethasone can also aid in the acute setting by decreasing spinal cord oedema and associated symptoms, improving patient comfort and quality of life. The degree of involvement within the epidural space and the extent of spinal cord displacement exhibit variability, and these considerations significantly influence treatment choices [ 3 2. Incidence The prevalence of MSCC among cancer patients varies between 0.2% and 7.9%, depending on the cancer type [ 1 2 4 1 2 4 5 5 5 3. Etiology and pathophysiology MSCC transpires due to hematogenous dissemination, initially affecting the vertebral body and subsequently encroaching upon the epidural space. This mechanism accounts for up to 85% of MSCC cases [ 1 6 1 7 8 9 The pathophysiology of MSCC is based on mechanical compression of the spinal cord, which triggers a sequence of secondary events. First, this compression raises venous hypertension and causes oedema in the white matter. These processes further compromise the arterial blood supply, eventually progressing to infarction of the cord parenchyma, leading to cellular death [ 1 7 1 4. Medical history The earliest possible intervention is crucial for a positive outcome for MSCC and requires an understanding of the range of presentations. Acute spinal cord compression caused by metastases has a variable and non-specific presentation, and patients might have atypical symptoms such as radicular pain, motor weakness, sensory disturbance, and autonomic dysfunction [ 10 11 10 11 Spinal cord metastases often present insidiously, with non-specific axial stiffness and pain, especially in patients with an underlying malignancy history. Progressive back pain, particularly at night or with recumbency, could be suggestive of vertebral metastasis. Radicular pain might suggest nerve root impingement by a metastatic tumour [ 10 11 10 11 10 11 5. Physical examination Although a thorough physical examination is integral to the initial evaluation of spinal cord compression, clinical findings can be nonspecific or absent, particularly in early or acute presentations. Combining physical examination with a high index of clinical suspicion and timely imaging is essential to ensure prompt diagnosis and management. Findings such as radicular pain, percussion tenderness, motor asymmetry, or sensory deficits and abnormalities, although not specific, are commonly seen in MSCC [ 12 12 The American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment scale (AIS) provides a structured framework for classifying spinal cord injuries based on detailed sensory and motor neurologic examination [ 13 14 13 14 13 14 In the ED, AIS can support rapid neurologic assessment and triage, determine the extent of spinal compromise and track any deterioration or change in the neurologic status. The ASIA scale is incorporated within the neurologic component of the NOMS framework, which helps to personalize MSCC treatment by integrating neurologic impairment with tumour behaviour, spinal stability, and overall health. Together, AIS and NOMS support evidence-based triage and care planning in the ED [ 15–19 17 19–23 6. Diagnostic imaging Urgent imaging is crucial when MSCC is suspected. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the entire spine is the gold standard [ 24 1 25 26 27 28 Table 1 3 7 Table 1. MSCC 6-point grading system developed by bilsky et al. [ 3 Grade Radiographic Characteristics Grade 0 Involvement limited to bone structures. Grade 1a Epidural impingement observed, but no deformation of the thecal sac. Grade 1b Epidural impingement causing deformation of the thecal sac, without spinal cord contact. Grade 1c Deformation of the thecal sac accompanied by spinal cord abutment. When MRI is not feasible due to specific patient factors, alternatives such as X-ray myelography or computed tomography of the spine with contrast can be considered [ 29 30–33 30 7. Initial management and emergency disposition Patients diagnosed with MSCC should be broadly categorized into distinct sub-groups, each demanding a tailored approach to patient disposition. Some cases necessitate immediate surgical decompression to alleviate spinal cord compression and prevent further neurological deterioration. In contrast, others might benefit significantly from prompt initiation of radiotherapy to mitigate tumour burden and relieve associated symptoms. For those with stable neurological function and adequate home support, safe discharge with diligent outpatient follow-up and palliative care support can be appropriate, ensuring continued monitoring of symptoms and treatment response. Additionally, certain patients might warrant placement in a clinical observation unit for 24 h, allowing for close surveillance of their neurological status and response to initial therapeutic interventions, thereby facilitating timely adjustment of the management plan based on emerging clinical insights. Stratifying these patients into distinct subgroups is crucial for optimizing outcomes and ensuring the timely delivery of appropriate interventions tailored to their unique clinical needs. MSCC is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to mitigate the risk of advancing neurological impairments. The urgency of intervention in cases of spinal cord compression is directly related to the rate of motor deficit development. When motor deficits evolve gradually over 7 days, it presents a more favourable scenario for retaining ambulatory function, and radiotherapy becomes a viable treatment option [ 34 34 34 Ideally, a tissue diagnosis will be established before steroid treatment begins because steroid therapy can alter cellular morphology, particularly in haematological malignancies [ 35 35 35 In general, glucocorticoids should be started for MSCC as early as possible, unless there are clear contraindications or there is diagnosis uncertainty. Following the completion of diagnostic procedures, glucocorticoids should be promptly initiated and not be postponed till after consultations, given that timely treatment can prevent functional decline, cord edema, and irreversible neurologic injury [ 20 21 36 37 19 20 36–38 19 36 37 39 40 40–42 43 Pain control related to MSCC often follows a stepwise pathway, starting with non-opioid analgesics (i.e. NSAIDs and paracetamol), mild opioids (codeine, tramadol) for mild to moderate breakthrough pain, and strong opioids (morphine, oxycodone, hydromorphone, transdermal fentanyl) for severe breakthrough pain [ 44 44 44 44 8. Frameworks for treatment decisions The NOMS (Neurologic, Oncologic, Mechanical, and Systemic) framework, mostly used in clinical practice, categorizes patients based on neurological criteria, distinguishing between low-grade (Grades 0–1) and high-grade (Grades 2–3) spinal cord compression [ 3 17 45 46 45 46 47–49 In addition to NOMS, the Spine Instability Neoplastic Score (SINS) criteria were established through expert consensus and incorporated six clinical and radiographic parameters, yielding a total score of 18. This scoring system aids in identifying patients with spinal instability, defined by a score exceeding 12, who are likely to benefit from surgical intervention [ 50 9. Role of radiotherapy and surgery Historically, surgical decompressive laminectomy was not found to be superior to RT alone for pain management and ambulation improvement in patients with MSCC [ 51–53 54 55 49 10. Prognosis Failure to promptly identify and treat MSCC can result in debilitating consequences, such as paraplegia, quadriplegia, sensory neuropathies, and impairments in bladder and bowel function, whose severity depends on the extent of spinal cord involvement. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for patients with acute MSCC, as delays can lead to permanent neurological damage with a low chance of recovery. The overall prognosis of MSCC is poor, with median survival ranging between 2.4 to 30 months and a one-year survival rate ranging between 12%-58% [ 56 56 57 58 11. Future directions While progress has been made in identifying optimal treatments for MSCC, unresolved questions remain, particularly for asymptomatic patients with intermediate- (Grades 1c-2) or high-grade (Grades 2–3) compression from less radiosensitive tumors. Current classification systems often categorize ESCC as low (Grades 0–1) or high grade, though some studies propose an intermediate category [ 45 59 45 59 Figure 1 12. Conclusion Metastatic spinal cord compression poses a significant challenge in the context of cancer care, demanding immediate clinical attention and precise management. Early detection and a multidisciplinary approach are the cornerstones of successful management. A prompt clinical assessment, urgent imaging, and, if necessary, tissue diagnosis play pivotal roles in shaping the course of treatment. The administration of steroids, the initiation of surgical interventions for specific cases, and the use of radiotherapy in conjunction with surgical decompression and stabilization contribute to improving patient outcomes. While the approach to treatment varies based on individual patient characteristics, the overarching goal remains preserving spinal cord function and alleviating neurological deficits.
